instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00850: What is 820-00850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V8_AWAKE: What is PP1V8_AWAKE? The PP1V8_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is indicative of a power rail that delivers 1.8 volts when the machine is in an "awake" state. This is not a traditional power state defined in the older Intel PCH documentation; it seems to be specific to newer MacBook architectures. The "awake" designation likely refers to a state where the MacBook is on and ready for user interaction, but it is not necessarily at full operational capacity (which would be denoted by an S0 state).
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP0V9_SSD0: What is PP0V9_SSD0? This is a power rail for the soldered on SSD on newer Macbooks. .
definitions.PP1V8_SSD0: What is PP1V8_SSD0? PP1V8_SSD0 is a power rail responsible for powering the soldered on NAND memory for the SSD on newer Macbook Pros.
definitions.PP3V3_G3S: What is PP3V3_G3S? PP3V3_G3S is a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in a G3S standby state. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi all,

Got this board with a dead cd3215c00, there was a crack in it. So thought easy peasy. Changed the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> with another one (ordered from ALI so not sure it was good) but still no 20v. Checked further and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was 6v. After further inspection saw that another <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (cd3215c00) was getting very hot. So changed that to and now I have 12,3V <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> but still no 20v and no PP1v1 ldo BMC on <CHIP>U3200</CHIP>/<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and UB400 (while connect on the corresponding port) Only on UB300...

I used like 3 other CD3215C00 chips all no bmc. Then I found a donor board with working 20v cd3215c00 chips. Got them off en reballed and still no BMC. So I know for SURE it can't be bad batch of <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. I read on this forum something about changing the TBT rom, I have a lot of donors but never did a ROM backup. (don't know how) and don't want to before im sure that could be my issue. 

Here are my readings:

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12,3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3,3v

<CHIP>U3200</CHIP> 
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC</SIGNAL> LDO BMC 0,484
PP1v8 LDOA 0.513
PP1v8 LDOD 0.470
PP3v3 LDO 0.459

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC</SIGNAL> LDO BMC 0,491
PP1v8 LDOA 0.505
PP1v8 LDOD 0.471
PP3v3 LDO 0.467

UB300
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC</SIGNAL> LDO BMC 0,507
PP1v8 LDOA 0.517
PP1v8 LDOD 0.481
PP3v3 LDO 0.496

UB400
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC</SIGNAL> LDO BMC 0,498
PP1v8 LDOA 0.510
PP1v8 LDOD 0.476
PP3v3 LDO 0.490

Please let me know if you need more info...

There is no power cycling, all ports stay at 5v and 0,35a

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
When a <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> dies cracking, is very bad; that means its die was melt and 20V spikes into data lines.
T2 and CPU could be damaged.

Did you try DFU?
Be aware, if important data on SSD, go for Revive option, not Restore.
If machine is not recognized in AC2, check if all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
It was a small crack on top as shown on picture. Seen it before so I directly knew this was the bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>. But after replacement and still no 20v I thought maybe a bad charger caused it and what clients do is try other ports. So thought maybe they destroyed more than one <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP>... 

Just tried DFU mode, can't get it in to DFU mode. Want to force dfu mode... Tried with with jumping a wire between pin 1 en 2 of RE032 still nothing... Am I doing something wrong?

[ATTACH type="full"]60647[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Onboard DFU force jumper must be closed when you plug the charger in.
Must open the jumper, once machine appears in AC2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Yeah did it like that, jumper between pin 1 en 2 but no duf mode...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Check if AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages are all there.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Hi back to this board again! Now I'm a little bit further... All ports behave same! 5v, 400ma (a lot of current I know) Also all LDO's are present. So don't think problem is there.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 12,3v So communication issue between T2 and <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

All awake and SLPS2R Voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 1,2v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 1,8v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> : 3.2v (was 0,2v and 2,8Ohm to ground after injecting 1 sec 3,3v in came back up) 
<SIGNAL>PPVDDCPU_AWAKE</SIGNAL>: 0,75v

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1,1v
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0,9v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 1,8v
<SIGNAL>PP0V82_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0,82v

Never could get it in DFU mode. I'm hoping duf mode can restore it?! Help please

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Still not getting 1V1 LDO?
In such case, there must be another problem on USB-C areas.

Test with original 87W charger and also battery connected.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No all LDO's are now present... Still not getting 12,6v on PPBUS and no DFU

edit: Also no 20v on charger

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Do you get any G3S, or SSD voltage?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
No G3S voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL>      0v                     diode mode 0.404
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL>    0v                     diode mode 0.321
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3S</SIGNAL>    0v                     diode mode 0.289

No SSD voltages:
<SIGNAL>PP2V7_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>    0v    diode mode 0.355
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SSD0</SIGNAL>                 0v    diode mode 0.347
<SIGNAL>PP0V9_SSD0</SIGNAL>                 0v    diode mode 0.325

Was onder the assumption that these came later... Do I need them to get in DFU mode? Sounds logical as the firmware has to be written on the SSD. 

Shouldn't we focus on why I don't have 12,6V onPPBUS? Is that not required before these come online?

Thxs in advance for the support

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
T2 firmware corruption will impede to get correct <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage.
G3S and SSD voltages can come back in DFU mode.

Not sure what is wrong on <SIGNAL>3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL>, as you've got short there first.
The culprit was masked after voltage injection, but not found.
If machine can't enter DFU, T2 is the first suspect.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Any more suggestions? I have a few donor boards... I can try to replace the T2. If it is possible at all? Otherwise I'm gonna trash the board... Customer didn't want it back anymore.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can change T2 and its SoC ROM (<CHIP>U4770</CHIP>) at same time.

First compare diode mode readings on USB-C lines of DFU port with the other ports.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I found a short on <SIGNAL>UPC_PMU_RESET</SIGNAL> 4,5ohm to ground. This is on all <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips and <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>. 

Can I safely inject voltage? How much do you suggest?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Start with 1V, no more than 3.5V...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
After injection voltage, UB400 was getting hot. replaced it and also UB300 Because there was a solder bolt on it side. So now al the <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> are changed. and still no 20v. Checked all LDO's and looking good. Still 5v and 0,425A on amp meter on all ports. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 12,3v
T2 is getting warm...

Can we get 20v without t2? So I want to know for sure t2 is dead before any attempt of changing it...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
T2 must talk with <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chips, in order to enable 20V on USB-C charger.
Did you try DFU mode after these changes?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Yeah first thing after not seeing 20v... Didi it in case with the keyboard combo and als with the force DFU. NO sign of live!

I'm guessing there is no other option left to change the T2.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
You can try flashing <CHIP>U2890</CHIP> and UB090 first.
Nothing to lose flashing <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> too.
Don't forget to backup all of them.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v 0,35A no corrosion no <SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Should I Flash or just change with donor board? Are there interchangeable?

I don't have <CHIP>U4770</CHIP> rom files...
